description: On 21 March the Government of Madagascar declared a Health State of Emergency (set to last two weeks, but extendable). UPDATE: The initial state of emergency declared on March 21, 2020 was set to last at least two weeks (until April 5). On April 5, the Malagasy president declared that it would be extended for another two weeks. The state of emergency includes the closure of all non-essential businesses, the suspension of public transport and a nationwide curfew from 20:00-05:00 (local time). The closure of schools, universities, churches and concert halls remain closed and public gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Malagasy President Andry Rajoelina announced on Sunday, March 22, 2020, that the country's two main cities, Antananarivo and Toamasina, will be locked down from Monday, March 23, to prevent further spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19). All individuals are required to stay at home and all transport, except for goods, will be prohibited. Only essential businesses, such as food stores and banks, will be allowed to remain open, and only one person per family will be allowed to shop.

description: In Madagascar, as of April 5, 2020, all schools, churches, and all public spaces (bars, restaurants, shops, karaokes, etc.) will remain closed until April 19th. UPDATE: The initial closure did not specify an end date but the government of Madagascar has now closed schools, churches, and all public spaces (bars, restaurants, shops, karaokes, etc.) until April 19th.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 23, 2020, the President of Madagascar announced that funeral services and vigils remain prohibited.

description: In Madagascar, as of April 5, 2020, no public gatherings of more than 50 people are allowed (family gatherings, etc.). UPDATE: In the original policy, public gatherings of more than 50 people were prohibited. UPDATE: As of October 5, 2020, authorities in Madagascar have eased public gathering restrictions, permitting groups of up to 200 to gather for religious, cultural, and sporting events.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Starting from April 4, 2021, gatherings of more than 100 people have been prohibited in the whole country.

description: President Andry Rajoelina announced that as of June 1, 2021, places of worship in Madagascar are now accessible but with limited capacity.

description: On June 27, 2021, Prime Minister of Madagascar Christian Ntsay announced that gathering of more than 400 people are prohibited, especially in the six districts where the virus is still actively circulating: Antananarivo-Renivohitra, Antananarivo Avaradrano, Antananarivo Atsimondrano, Ambohidratrimo, Ambatondrazaka and Fianarantsoa 1.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Antananarivo-Renivohitra (Analamanga); Antananarivo Avaradrano (Analamanga); Antananarivo Atsimondrano (Analamanga);  Ambohidratrimo (Analamanga); Ambatondrazaka (Alaotra-Mangoro); Fianarantsoa 1 (Haute Matsiatra)

description: In Madagascar, as of April 10, 2020, everyone must wear a face mask (or scarf that covers one's mouth and nose) while in the capital of Antananarivo. Anyone caught outside without a mask on will be detained by the police.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: From April 21 2020,  the maximum number of passengers in buses (taxibe) will be limited to 18 per bus. Transporting standing passengers is strictly forbidden.
